text.content: Click a Lesson or Activity to learn more about Supporting Early Childhood Development.
By setting aside your cultural biases, you can influence parents' efforts within their own cultural context.

Parents can provide an environment that:
  • Is safe
  • Facilitates development and promotes health
  • Allows children to explore and engage in meaningful activities

Parents can also provide relationships that:
  • Are responsive to the child's needs, developmental level, and temperament
  • Are predictable and consistent
  • Value the child

Key Messages:
  • Relationships can buffer the effects of an adverse environment. A child's relationship with his or her parent is crucial to the child's development, especially if the family faces poverty, discrimination, violence, or displacement.
  • By being sensitive to the cultural background of parents, professionals can work towards optimal child development outcomes while respecting the importance of culture within a family and community.

audio.transcript: By setting aside your cultural biases, you can influence parents' efforts within their own cultural context.
Parents can be encouraged to provide an environment that is safe, facilitates development and promotes health, and allows children to explore and engage in meaningful activities.

You can also encourage parents to provide relationships that are responsive to the child's needs, developmental level, and temperament. And relationships that are predictable and consistent, and value the child.

The key messages to remember are that relationships can buffer the effects of an adverse environment. A child's relationship with his or her parent is crucial to the child's development, especially if the family faces poverty, discrimination, violence, or displacement. By being sensitive to the cultural background of parents, professionals can work towards optimal child development outcomes while respecting the importance of culture within a family and community.

text.content:
A child's safety plays a larger role than the parent-child relationship in a violent situation. For example, if a parent is violent or abusive, the parent is clearly not contributing to the child's development and in many cases the child would be taken away from the parent.

Most professionals who work with children are "mandated reporters," meaning that they are required to seek help for a child that is being maltreated, neglected, or exposed to violence. These circumstances negatively impact a child's development and well-being across cultures. In order for a child to benefit from the parent-child relationship, the child first needs to be safe.
